resources.string: The Graduate Record Examinations, often known as GRE, are conducted by Educational Testing Services (ETS). Broadly categorised, there are two types of GRE - GRE General Test and GRE Subject Tests. The GRE tests are one of the most widely accepted tests across the world.

string.name: gre_general_learn_more
string.u: Learn more about the GRE General Test

string.name: gre_subject_learn_more
string.u: Learn more about the GRE Subject Tests

resources.string: The GRE General Test is a widely accepted test for masters, doctorate and other specialised programs. The test consists of three types of sections.
This section type tests your thinking and analytical skills by requiring you write you an essay based on the instructions provided.
This section type tests your ability to understand the text, analyse and draw conclusions by requiring you to solve various types of Verbal Reasoning questions.
This section type tests your ability to interpret and analyse quantitative information by requiring you to solve various types of Quantitative Reasoning questions.
The GRE General Test is available in two modes - computer-delivered and paper-delivered.

The computer-delivered test requires you have prerequisite knowledge about operating a basic computer in the testing environment. It comes with additional features compared to the paper-delivered test.
The paper-delivered test does not require you to have any prerequisite knowledge, but has its own limitations compared to the computer-delivered test.

You are required to attempt a total of 6 sections:

 - 1 AWA-Measure section (1 hr)
 - 2 V-Measure sections (30 min each)
 - 2 Q-Measure sections (35 min each)
 - 1 Experimental section (30 min or 35 min)

The order of sections in the test is:

1. AWA-Measure
2. V-Measure 1 or Q-Measure 1
3. Q-Measure 1 or V-Measure 1
 --- 10 min break --- 
4. V-Measure 2 or Q-Measure 2
5. Q-Measure 2 or V-Measure 2
6. V-Measure 3 or Q-Measure 3

- The experimental section can be a V-Measure section or a Q-Measure section.

 - It can appear anywhere in the test after the AWA section.

 - There is no way to determine whether a section in the test is experimental. For example, if you get 3 V-Measure sections and 2 Q-Measure sections in the test, it can be inferred that one of those V-Measure sections was experimental. However, there is absolutely no way to determine which one of those sections was experimental.

 - The experimental section does not count towards your ultimate score.

- You get a 1 min break after the end of each section. You are not allowed to leave your desk during this break.

 - After the end of the third section, you get a 10 min break. You are allowed to leave your desk during this break.

 - All the breaks are optional. One may chose to skip any of the breaks.
The total duration of the computer-delivered test is around 4 hours, depending upon the combination of sections that you get on the test.

The computer-delivered test provides the following features:

 - You can skip a question within a section. However, you cannot skip a section. You have to submit and end a section to proceed with another section.

 - You can change or edit your answer for a question at any point of time within a section.

 - You can mark a question and review it later at any point of time within a section.

 - You can get overall preview of the section at any point of time within a section.

 - On-screen calculator is available for Q-Measure sections.
